conversation.message:
Hi Company_D—thanks for sharing the near-term gap. Per your note, here are (1) examples, (2) my strongest stack, and (3) a concrete 30/60/90 for taking a manual workflow to “measurably faster + reliable.”

(1) 2–3 relevant end-to-end ownership examples
- Internal ops workflow automation: Took a multi-step, spreadsheet-driven intake + routing process owned by 6 stakeholders. Mapped the current state, defined cycle-time + error-rate metrics, then implemented an automated queue with validation + audit logs. Result: cycle time down ~40–60%, fewer handoff errors, and clearer ownership via runbooks + dashboards.
- Reliability/guardrails on an internal service: Added structured logging, metrics, alerting, and idempotent job handling to a flaky batch process. Introduced retries/backoff, dead-letter handling, and a lightweight on-call playbook. Result: incidents dropped materially and recoveries became predictable.
- Cross-functional rollout: Led adoption for a new internal tool by pairing with 2 power users, running short enablement sessions, and iterating on UX + docs based on weekly feedback. Result: sustained usage and fewer “shadow” manual workarounds.

(2) Tools/stack I’m strongest with
Python, SQL, and TypeScript; REST/queue-based integrations; Postgres; ETL/workflow tooling; basic infra + observability (dashboards/alerts, structured logs, tracing); pragmatic automation with strong error handling + runbooks.

(3) 30/60/90 plan for your workflow problem
- First 0–30 days: Stakeholder interviews + process mapping; define success metrics (cycle time, touch points, error rate, rework rate); identify top 2 bottlenecks; ship quick wins (validation, templates, clearer handoffs); add baseline instrumentation.
- Days 31–60: Build/extend the automation path end-to-end (routing, approvals, notifications); add guardrails (idempotency, retries, dead-lettering, audit trail); write runbooks; pilot with a small group; measure deltas vs baseline.
- Days 61–90: Harden reliability + scale rollout; refine UX; finalize dashboards + alerts; document ownership + escalation paths; drive full adoption and retire the manual path where safe.

If you’re still open to a contingency option, I’d be glad to share a 1–2 page write-up tailored to the specific workflow and stakeholders you have in mind (even anonymized). What is the workflow domain (e.g., finance ops, customer onboarding, data QA, internal IT requests), and what tools/systems does it touch today?

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D—appreciate the added context. Below is the tailored write-up (structured so you can drop it into a doc). Happy to expand into a 1–2 pager with diagrams if helpful.

1) Proposed metrics + dashboard (baseline + ongoing)
Goal: make “where is this onboarding/billing request stuck?” obvious, and measure cycle-time improvements.
- Core funnel metrics (overall + by segment: region, product, ACV, plan type)
  - End-to-end cycle time: Intake submitted → NetSuite customer + billing setup complete
  - Stage cycle times:
    1) Intake submitted → Intake validated
    2) Validated → Routed/assigned (Sales Ops/Finance/Support)
    3) Assigned → Approvals complete
    4) Approvals → NetSuite setup complete
    5) NetSuite setup → “Ready for Support/Go-live”
  - Rework rate: % requests sent back for missing/invalid data
  - SLA compliance: % within target per stage
  - WIP + aging: count of open requests by stage; # aged > X days
  - Top rejection reasons: missing fields, mismatched account IDs, tax/VAT issues, billing terms missing, etc.
- Operational views
  - Queue view by owner/team with aging + next action
  - “Blocked” reasons taxonomy (awaiting customer info, awaiting finance approval, SFDC data mismatch, etc.)
- Instrumentation approach
  - Single request ID propagated across systems (Form/Jira/SFDC/NetSuite notes or custom field)
  - Event log table (request_id, event_type, timestamp, actor/system) to compute cycle times reliably

2) First two automation thin slices to ship (highest leverage, lowest risk)
Thin Slice #1 (Week 1–2): Intake validation + standardized routing
- Replace/augment the shared form/spreadsheet with a structured intake (could still be the existing form, but with stricter schema): required fields, dropdowns, conditional logic.
- Real-time validation rules (examples):
  - SFDC Account/Opportunity must exist and be in correct stage
  - Billing contact + legal entity fields required
  - Terms fields constrained to allowed values
- Auto-create a Jira Service Desk ticket with:
  - Pre-filled structured fields
  - Linked SFDC Account/Opportunity
  - Auto-assignment based on rules (region/product/plan type)
- Outcome: immediate reduction in rework + clearer ownership; creates the event log backbone.

Thin Slice #2 (Week 2–4): “Approval + handoff” automation with visibility
- Add a lightweight state machine around the Jira ticket (or equivalent): Submitted → Validated → Finance Review → Approved → NetSuite Setup → Complete.
- Automate approvals:
  - Finance approval triggered when specific conditions met (e.g., non-standard terms, tax/VAT complexity)
  - SLA timers + reminders; escalate if aging > threshold
- Auto-sync back to SFDC:
  - Write status + timestamps to SFDC fields for Sales visibility
- Outcome: fewer manual pings; measurable stage cycle time; reduces “black box” handoffs.

3) Data validation + ownership across SFDC → NetSuite (pragmatic governance)
Principle: define “source of truth” per field and enforce it at the boundary.
- Source of truth (example policy)
  - Customer identity + sales context: SFDC (Account/Opportunity)
  - Billing configuration + invoicing/tax setup: NetSuite
  - Process state + workflow audit trail: Jira + event log
- Validation strategy
  - Pre-flight checks before NetSuite setup begins:
    - Required SFDC fields present and locked for the request (snapshot key fields at time of validation)
    - Ensure consistent identifiers (SFDC Account ID mapped to NetSuite customer ID once created)
  - Field-level ownership rules:
    - If a field is owned by SFDC, updates must happen in SFDC; automation reads from SFDC and writes derived/status fields back.
    - If a field is owned by NetSuite, SFDC stores reference/summary only (avoid dual-edit).
- Sync approach (thin, safe integration)
  - Start with “status + ID sync” first (low risk): once NetSuite customer is created, write NetSuite customer ID back to SFDC + Jira.
  - Then expand to controlled data sync where needed (e.g., billing terms) with clear conflict rules.
- Guardrails
  - Idempotency keys for integrations (avoid duplicate NetSuite customers)
  - Error handling + dead-letter queue for failed syncs
  - Audit trail: who/what changed which critical fields and when

If helpful, I can turn this into a clean 1–2 page doc with a simple diagram of systems + request states.
Two quick questions so I can tailor it even tighter:
1) Do you already have an integration layer (e.g., MuleSoft/Workato/Zapier/custom) between SFDC and NetSuite, or is it mostly manual today?
2) What’s the most common failure mode right now: missing intake fields, incorrect tax/entity info, or approval latency?

Also—what’s your expected timeline for finalizing the hire? If your top choice doesn’t close, I’d be very interested in being next in line.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D — great question. For Thin Slice #1, I’d anchor the *workflow/state machine* in **Jira Service Desk**, with **SFDC as the system of record** for Account/Opportunity + core customer data.

**Why Jira as the workflow anchor (state machine):**
- **Cross-functional execution + queueing:** Sales Ops / Finance / Support already live in ticket queues; Jira gives clear ownership, WIP limits, SLAs, and handoffs without forcing everyone to operate inside SFDC.
- **Auditability + operability:** Jira is strong for an auditable trail of “who did what when,” plus comments/attachments/runbooks; it’s also easier to add reminders/escalations for approval latency.
- **Faster to ship thin slice #1:** Create a single structured intake → auto-create Jira ticket with required fields + routing rules. This gets you immediate rework reduction and visibility with minimal SFDC object/model changes.

**How SFDC fits (still first-class):**
- SFDC remains **source of truth** for customer/opportunity fields; the intake validation step checks required SFDC fields (and/or snapshots key fields at validation time).
- Jira writes back **status + timestamps + request_id** to SFDC so Sales has real-time visibility (no black box), but we avoid duplicating editable data fields in two places.

**Integration approach (pragmatic):**
- Use Workato where it’s reliable (ticket creation, field sync, notifications), and a small custom job/service for the parts needing stronger **idempotency/audit/event-log** (e.g., request_id propagation, retries, dead-lettering, NetSuite customer creation safeguards later).

If you prefer SFDC as the workflow anchor, I can make that work too—typically I’d do that only if (a) most approvers/operators truly live in SFDC day-to-day, or (b) you need tight coupling to CPQ/Opportunity stage gates. Given your current pain (missing intake fields + manual routing + visibility across teams), Jira-first for the state machine tends to unblock fastest.

Happy to go one level deeper on what the Jira states/fields would be and the exact SFDC fields I’d sync back in the first iteration.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D — absolutely. Below are concrete bullets for Thin Slice #1 + the Workato pieces + relevant SFDC/NetSuite integration experience.

1) Jira Service Desk workflow (states) + required fields (intake vs “Validated”)
**States (JSM request type: “Customer Onboarding + Billing Setup”)**
- **Submitted (Intake Received)**
- **Intake Triage (Auto / Ops Review)**
- **Validated (Ready for Routing)**
- **In Progress – Finance Review (if needed)**
- **In Progress – Billing Setup (NetSuite)**
- **Blocked (Waiting on Info / Approval)**
- **Complete (Billing Setup Done)**
- **Cancelled / Duplicate**

**Fields (structured, mostly dropdowns + entity refs; all captured on the ticket)**
Core identifiers
- SFDC Account ID (required at intake)
- SFDC Opportunity ID (required at intake, unless you support “account-only” onboarding)
- Request ID (generated automatically)
- Region / Segment / Product / Plan (derived from SFDC where possible)

Customer/billing essentials
- Legal entity (required at intake; dropdown)
- Billing contact (required at intake; name + email)
- Bill-to address (required at intake)
- Currency (required at intake)
- Payment terms (required at intake; dropdown with “Standard/Non-standard” + free-text only if non-standard)
- Tax/VAT applicability (optional at intake; required by “Validated” if certain countries/regions)

Operational fields
- Requested go-live date (optional at intake; required by Validated if provided by Sales)
- Attachments (order form / SOW) (optional at intake; required by Validated if non-standard terms)
- Finance approval required? (boolean; computed at validation)
- NetSuite Customer ID (blank until later)

**What’s enforced when**
- **At Intake (hard-stop validation):** SFDC Account+Opp exist, billing contact present, legal entity present, terms present, address present, currency present. Also enforce allowed values (no free-form for entity/terms).
- **At “Validated” (ops gate before routing):**
  - Snapshot key SFDC fields (legal entity, billing contact, terms, address) into ticket custom fields + event log
  - Confirm Opp stage is appropriate (e.g., Closed Won / ready-for-onboarding)
  - Determine routing + whether Finance Review is required (non-standard terms, certain tax flags, etc.)
  - If any required artifact is missing (e.g., order form for non-standard), ticket moves to **Blocked – Waiting on Info** with an auto-comment to Sales listing missing items.

2) Workato recipes + where request_id + event log live
**High-level principle:** Workato is great for orchestration + field sync; I’d keep *request_id generation + event log writes* in a small, durable service (or a lightweight DB-backed job) so we can guarantee idempotency, retries, and an append-only audit trail.

**Recipe A: Intake → Jira ticket creation + routing**
- Trigger: SFDC (new “Onboarding Request” signal). This can be:
  - a simple SFDC Flow/button that creates an “Onboarding Requested” record/event, OR
  - a dedicated custom object “Onboarding_Request__c” created by Sales Ops.
- Steps:
  1) Call **Request Registry service**: `POST /requests` with SFDC account_id, opp_id (idempotency key = opp_id + request_type). Service returns `request_id`.
  2) Pull required SFDC fields (Account, Opp, billing contact fields, terms, etc.).
  3) Validate (Workato can do basic checks; for strict schema I’d also have the Registry service validate and return explicit missing-field errors).
  4) Create Jira Service Desk request with:
     - request_id
     - all structured fields

  5) Write back to SFDC: Jira key/link + request_id + initial status + timestamps.
  6) Event-log write: Registry service appends events: REQUEST_CREATED, JIRA_CREATED, VALIDATION_FAILED (if applicable).

**Recipe B: Jira status/field changes → SFDC status + timestamps**
- Trigger: Jira webhook (issue updated / transitioned).
- Steps:
  1) Map Jira status → SFDC status field (e.g., Submitted, Validated, Finance Review, NetSuite Setup, Complete, Blocked).
  2) Write timestamps in SFDC for each milestone (first time entering each state).
  3) Post a comment back to Jira if SFDC update fails (visibility).
  4) Event-log write: call Registry service `POST /events` with request_id + event_type + timestamp + actor.

**Where request_id generation + event log live**
- **Request_id generation:** Registry service (DB-backed) to ensure global uniqueness + idempotency (avoid two tickets for same Opp).
- **Event log:** Same service/DB (append-only table keyed by request_id). Workato/Jira/SFDC all call it; it becomes the authoritative timeline for cycle-time metrics.

3) SFDC ↔ NetSuite experience + what went wrong + idempotency/duplicates
- I’ve integrated SFDC → downstream billing/ERP systems in a couple environments (NetSuite once in a partial capacity; more commonly SFDC → internal billing services / accounting platforms). The recurring failure modes were very similar:
  - **Duplicate customer creation** when retries happened (timeouts) or when two ops users triggered “create customer” in parallel.
  - **Field drift / dual-edit** (Sales edits billing address/terms in SFDC after Finance has already begun setup).
  - **Brittle matching** (name-based matching instead of stable IDs) leading to merges/manual cleanup.

**How I handled idempotency + duplicates (pragmatic pattern):**
- Introduce a **single external key** used for customer creation calls (e.g., `external_customer_key = SFDC_Account_ID` or `request_id` depending on model).
- Before “create” in NetSuite: **lookup by external key**; if exists, treat as success and return the existing NetSuite ID.
- Store the NetSuite ID back in SFDC + Jira immediately (status+ID sync first).
- Use an **outbox/event-log** or durable job queue for the create/update calls:
  - Retries with backoff
  - Dead-lettering + alerting
  - Exactly-once semantics at the business level via idempotency key
- Prevent dual-edit by defining ownership:
  - Once request hits “Validated”, lock/snapshot key billing fields for that request (or require a change-control comment + re-validation if Sales must change terms).

If you want, I can also sketch the exact field mapping for “status + timestamps” back into SFDC (minimal set) and the first dashboard slices (cycle time + rework reasons + WIP aging) using the event log.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D — as requested, below is a tight “Thin Slice #1” execution packet you can implement immediately.

A) JSM workflow (states, transitions, required fields)
Request type: Customer Onboarding + Billing Setup

States
1) Submitted
2) Intake Triage
3) Validated
4) In Progress – Finance Review (conditional)
5) In Progress – Billing Setup (NetSuite)
6) Blocked – Waiting on Info / Revalidation
7) Complete
8) Cancelled / Duplicate

Transitions (with key guards)
- Submitted → Intake Triage (auto on creation)
- Intake Triage → Validated (requires validation pass)
- Intake Triage → Blocked (missing/invalid fields)
- Blocked → Intake Triage (when missing info provided)
- Validated → Finance Review (if non-standard terms / approval required)
- Finance Review → Validated (approved; returns to Validated “ready for billing setup”)
- Validated → Billing Setup (when Finance not required OR after approval)
- Billing Setup → Complete
- Any → Cancelled/Duplicate (with reason)

Required fields
At Intake (hard-stop to create/submit request)
- SFDC Account ID (text)
- SFDC Opportunity ID (text; allow exception only if you explicitly support account-only)
- Billing contact name + email
- Bill-to address (structured fields or single text)
- Legal entity (dropdown)
- Currency (dropdown)
- Payment terms (dropdown) + “Non-standard terms details” (required iff non-standard)
- Region/segment/product (prefer derived from SFDC; required on ticket either way)

At “Validated” gate (must be present to transition)
- Order form/SOW attachment (required iff non-standard terms)
- Approval required? (computed boolean)
- Validation snapshot version (e.g., v1, v2)
- Revalidation required? = false

Operational fields (not required initially)
- NetSuite Customer ID (later)
- Requested go-live date (optional; if present, enforce format)

B) SFDC fields + Flow/validation triggers for “Revalidation Required”
Minimal SFDC fields to add (either on Opportunity or a small custom object “Onboarding_Request__c”)
- Onboarding_Request_ID__c (stores Jira key, e.g., ONB-123)
- Onboarding_Status__c (mirrors Jira status)
- Onboarding_Validated_At__c (datetime)
- Onboarding_Completed_At__c (datetime)
- Onboarding_Revalidation_Required__c (checkbox)
- Onboarding_Validated_Snapshot_Version__c (text/number)
- Onboarding_Last_Synced_From_Jira__c (datetime)

Flow: “Set Revalidation Required on key-field change”
Trigger: record update (Account and/or Opportunity; whichever owns the billing fields in your org)
Condition:
- Onboarding_Request_ID__c is not blank AND Onboarding_Status__c is in {Validated, Finance Review, Billing Setup}
- AND any of these fields changed: Legal entity, billing contact, billing address, payment terms, currency (and any other fields you deem critical)
Actions:
- Set Onboarding_Revalidation_Required__c = true
- (Optional) increment a “pending snapshot” counter or set a Changed_Fields__c text summary for the Workato comment

Validation rule (lightweight): don’t hard-lock edits; instead surface a warning
- Allow changes, but require a reason field OR automatically mark revalidation required (Flow does this). This avoids brittle blocking.

C) Workato recipes (with failure modes + duplicate prevention + retries/alerts + compensation)

Recipe 1: SFDC “Onboarding Requested” → Create/Update Jira + route
Trigger options (pick one):
- Preferred: creation of Onboarding_Request__c
- Alternative: Opportunity field “Onboarding Requested” toggled true

Steps
1) Duplicate prevention (primary):
- If SFDC already has Onboarding_Request_ID__c populated, STOP (no new Jira)
2) Create Jira Service Desk request/issue:
- Set request type
- Map required fields
- Set initial status Submitted (auto to Intake Triage)
3) Write back to SFDC:
- Onboarding_Request_ID__c = Jira key
- Onboarding_Status__c = Submitted
- Store Jira URL
4) Routing:
- Set assignee/queue based on region/product/segment rules

Failure modes + handling
- Jira create fails (timeout/API error):
  - Retry with exponential backoff (e.g., 3 attempts)
  - If still failing: alert Slack/Email + write SFDC error field (optional)
- Duplicate Jira created due to race:
  - Before create, do Jira search by SFDC Opp ID / Account ID custom field; if found, link that and write it back to SFDC (compensation)

Recipe 2: Jira issue transitioned/updated → Sync status + timestamps to SFDC (+ revalidation loop)
Trigger: Jira webhook on issue updated/transitioned

Steps
1) Locate SFDC record by Onboarding_Request_ID__c == Jira key
2) Map Jira status → SFDC Onboarding_Status__c
3) Milestone timestamps:
- If status enters Validated first time, set Onboarding_Validated_At__c if blank
- If status enters Complete first time, set Onboarding_Completed_At__c if blank
4) Revalidation loop:
- If Jira moves to Blocked – Revalidation, set Onboarding_Revalidation_Required__c = true
- If Jira moves to Validated, set Onboarding_Revalidation_Required__c = false and increment Snapshot_Version

Failure modes + handling
- SFDC update fails:
  - Retry (e.g., 3 attempts)
  - If still failing: comment on Jira tagging ops channel + alert
- Out-of-order events:
  - Use “last synced from Jira” timestamp; ignore older webhook payloads

Earliest start / sprint / engagement
- Earliest start date: immediately.
- I can do a focused 2–4 week sprint to ship Thin Slice #1 end-to-end (intake → Jira → routing → SFDC visibility + revalidation loop) and leave docs/runbooks.
- Preferred structure: contract-to-hire, but I’m also open to a straight 2–4 week contract sprint if that’s easier.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D — absolutely. Below are the concrete pieces.

1) Pre-create duplicate-check JQL template
Assumptions:
- Project key: ONB (adjust)
- Custom fields:
  - “SFDC Opportunity ID” = customfield_12345
  - “SFDC Account ID” = customfield_23456
  - “Onboarding Type” (single-select) = customfield_34567
- Statuses to exclude: Complete, Cancelled/Duplicate

Primary (OppID + OnboardingType):
```
project = ONB
AND "SFDC Opportunity ID" ~ "${OPP_ID}"
AND "Onboarding Type" = "${ONBOARDING_TYPE}"
AND status NOT IN (Complete, "Cancelled / Duplicate")
ORDER BY created DESC
```
Notes:
- I use `~` (contains) because some Jira instances don’t allow `=` on text custom fields depending on configuration; if `=` is supported for the field type, prefer `=` for exact match.

Secondary fallback (AccountID + OnboardingType) when OppID isn’t available / multi-opp onboarding:
```
project = ONB
AND "SFDC Account ID" ~ "${ACCOUNT_ID}"
AND "Onboarding Type" = "${ONBOARDING_TYPE}"
AND status NOT IN (Complete, "Cancelled / Duplicate")
ORDER BY created DESC
```
Optional tightening if you add a Go-Live Month field (recommended for multi-opp cases):
```
... AND "Go-Live Month" = "${YYYY-MM}"
```

Operational behavior in Workato:
- Run Primary query first.
- If ≥1 hit, pick the most recent non-cancelled ticket and write its key back to SFDC (compensation).
- Else run Secondary query; if hit, either (a) append the OppID to “Related Opportunity IDs” and reuse the ticket, or (b) create a new ticket but link them explicitly (depends on your policy).

2) Recommended Jira custom field formats / normalization
Goal: avoid “almost matches” and make searching reliable.

A) Field types
- SFDC Opportunity ID: **Text (single line)**
- SFDC Account ID: **Text (single line)**
- Related Opportunity IDs (optional): **Text (multi-line)** or **Labels** (if you want tokenized search)

B) Format enforcement
- Prefer **18-character IDs** (case-insensitive) stored as uppercase.
- Enforce via:
  1) JSM portal help text + examples
  2) Workato normalization step before Jira create/update:
     - trim whitespace
     - uppercase
     - if 15-char provided, convert to 18-char if you have a converter available; otherwise accept 15 but store a normalized “canonical” version in a second hidden field (or always re-pull from SFDC and overwrite with the 18-char).

C) Validation approach (practical)
- I’d avoid heavy Jira regex validators unless your admins are comfortable maintaining them.
- Instead:
  - Portal: required field + description “paste 18-char SFDC ID”
  - Workato: if not matching `^[A-Z0-9]{15}([A-Z0-9]{3})?$`, transition to Blocked with an auto-comment and do not proceed.

If you tell me your actual Jira project key + the customfield IDs/names you’re using (or a screenshot of the field config), I can rewrite the JQL exactly for your instance (using `=` vs `~` appropriately).

Also confirming: I remain available for a 2–4 week sprint at 35–40 hrs/week if you need to activate quickly.

1) SFDC ID custom fields (to maximize `=` exact-match JQL)

  - Recipe #1: SFDC “Onboarding Requested” → Jira create + routing + write-back
    - Duplicate prevention: don’t create if Jira key already exists; pre-create JQL check for existing active ticket.

Hi Company_D — absolutely. Below are the two items you requested (kickoff agenda + Day-1 access checklist) so you can activate within 24–48 hours if needed.

A) 30-minute kickoff agenda (Thin Slice #1)
0–5 min — Goals + success criteria
- Confirm Thin Slice #1 objective: reduce rework from missing/invalid intake data; clear routing/ownership; SFDC visibility; revalidation loop.
- Confirm acceptance criteria + what “done” means for the sprint.

5–10 min — Current-state walkthrough (10k-foot)
- Current intake path (form/spreadsheet) → Jira/JSM usage → SFDC fields/objects involved.
- Known pain points + top 3 edge cases.

10–18 min — System decisions + scope locks for Slice #1
- Confirm Jira/JSM as workflow anchor; SFDC as source of truth for customer/opportunity data.
- Confirm required fields + conditional logic (non-standard terms, attachments).
- Confirm de-dupe key: OppID + OnboardingType; multi-opp policy (Related Opp IDs labels).

18–25 min — Implementation plan + owners
- Jira/JSM admin tasks (fields, workflow, request type).
- SFDC admin tasks (fields, Flow for revalidation flag).
- Workato tasks (2 recipes + connections + alerting).
- Decide comms: activation via email, then Slack channel + escalation path.

25–30 min — Access check + next steps
- Validate all access is granted.
- Agree on day-1 deliverables and day-2 demo checkpoint.

B) Day-1 access checklist (by system)

1) Jira / Jira Service Management (JSM)
Required access
- Jira Admin or Project Admin for the target JSM project (create/edit request types, forms, workflows, screens).
- Permission to create/edit:
  - Custom fields (SFDC Account ID, SFDC Opportunity ID, Onboarding Type, Related Opportunity IDs (Labels), optional Go-Live Month)
  - Workflow statuses + transitions + transition conditions/validators
  - Automation rules (if you prefer Jira Automation for some notifications)
- Ability to view issue changelog/history (for audit + metrics).

Prereqs/configs
- Confirm project key (e.g., ONB) and the final customfield IDs.
- Confirm status names to use (exact strings) so Workato mappings are stable.
- Confirm request type name and portal location.

Credentials
- Jira API token or OAuth app credentials (depending on your standard).


2) Salesforce (SFDC)
Required access
- Admin (or delegated admin + paired SFDC admin) to:
  - Create/update fields on Opportunity or Onboarding_Request__c (Jira key/link, status, timestamps, revalidation flag, snapshot/version)
  - Create/modify Flow(s) that set Revalidation Required on key-field change
  - Add permission sets/field-level security as needed
- Read access to the canonical billing fields and identifiers (AccountId, OpportunityId, terms, billing contact, legal entity, address, currency).

Prereqs/configs
- Confirm where the “Onboarding Requested” trigger lives (custom object vs Opportunity flag/Flow/button).
- Confirm the exact list of “key billing fields” that should trigger revalidation.

Credentials
- Integration user (recommended) for Workato with least-privilege permissions.


3) Workato
Required access
- Workato workspace access with ability to:
  - Create/edit/deploy recipes
  - Manage connections (SFDC + Jira)
  - Configure error handling (retries/backoff) and notifications
  - View job history/logs

Connections/credentials needed
- Salesforce connection (integration user)
- Jira connection (API token/OAuth)
- Notification target (Slack connector or email) for failure alerts

Prereqs/configs
- Decide the alerting channel (Slack channel name) and who is on-call for recipe failures.
- Confirm whether you want callable recipes vs two standalone recipes.

Day-1 deliverables I’d target once access is live
- Finalize exact JQL using your project key + customfield IDs (prefer exact-match `=` where supported).
- Draft both Workato recipes end-to-end in “test mode” with stub data.
- Jira/JSM: create the request type + fields + initial workflow skeleton.
- SFDC: create the minimal fields and the revalidation Flow skeleton.

If you want, I can also add a one-page “roles/permissions matrix” (who needs what) for your admins, but the above should be enough to keep on file.

Keeping aligned with your note: I’ll wait for your activation email (vendor portal + access path + project key/customfield IDs).

conversation.message:
Hi Company_D — sharing the optional routing rules table template you mentioned (no vendor/compliance overhead). You can copy/paste this into a sheet and fill it in internally.

Routing Rules Table (Template)

Columns
- Rule_ID (e.g., R-001)
- Onboarding_Type (New / Expansion / Billing Change / Other)
- Region (e.g., NA / EMEA / APAC)
- Segment (e.g., SMB / Mid-Market / Enterprise)
- Product / Plan (free text or dropdown)
- Currency (optional)
- Country / Tax_Region (optional; for VAT/GST handling)
- Non_Standard_Terms? (Y/N)
- Finance_Approval_Required? (Y/N) — rule expression (see below)
- Target_Jira_Queue (e.g., “RevOps Onboarding – NA”)
- Default_Assignee (optional; if blank, queue-based)
- SLA_Target (e.g., Validate in 1 business day)
- Escalation_Path (e.g., Slack channel / manager)
- Notes / Exceptions

Suggested “Finance_Approval_Required” rule expression (examples)
- If Non_Standard_Terms = Y → Finance_Approval_Required = Y
- If Payment_Terms not in {Net 30, Net 45} → Y
- If Country in {…VAT countries list…} AND Tax fields incomplete → Y
- If Currency not in {USD} (or your standard set) → Y

Example rows (illustrative)
- R-001 | New | NA | SMB | Core | USD | (blank) | N | N | Queue: RevOps Onboarding – NA | (blank) | Validate <1bd | #revops-onboarding | Standard path
- R-002 | New | EMEA | Enterprise | Core+Add-on | EUR | DE | N | Y (VAT) | Queue: RevOps Onboarding – EMEA | (blank) | Validate <1bd | #revops-onboarding | VAT review
- R-003 | Expansion | NA | Mid-Market | Core | USD | (blank) | Y | Y | Queue: Finance Review | (blank) | Finance <2bd | #finance-approvals | Non-standard terms

If you want, I can also provide a companion “field-to-queue mapping” section (which SFDC/Jira fields feed each column) so your admins can implement routing deterministically.

Still on standby through your Thursday EOD checkpoint next week (ET), and can start within 24–48 hours of access if you decide to trigger the sprint.
